Travel_History_Narrative.History of Travel Narrative: Patient reports recent travel within Louisiana and Mississippi. Notably, he visited Baton Rouge from May 10-12, 2024, staying with family and attending social gatherings. On March 15, 2024, he traveled within New Orleans for a routine health check-up, using public transportation. In November 2023, he spent two days in Biloxi, Mississippi, engaging in social activities including visiting a casino. While these travels do not present significant risk factors for hepatitis C transmission, the patient's visit to a casino and reported stop at a neighborhood bar after a clinic visit could potentially involve exposure to high-risk environments. It's important to note that hepatitis C is not typically spread through casual contact, but the patient's activities in these locations may warrant further discussion regarding potential risk behaviors.

Practitioner_Documents.Reason for Visit: Fatigue, abdominal discomfort, and follow-up for chronic hepatitis C with compensated cirrhosis
Practitioner_Documents.Past Medical History: Patient has a history of chronic hepatitis C diagnosed in 2015, with progression to compensated cirrhosis confirmed in 2020. He has a history of alcohol use disorder, now in remission since 2018. He also has hypertension, diagnosed in 2019 and currently managed with medication. The patient has a history of depression, diagnosed in 2016, for which he receives ongoing treatment. He underwent an appendectomy in 2000 and has a history of recurrent urinary tract infections, with the last episode in 2022.
Practitioner_Documents.Review of Systems: General: Reports fatigue and unintentional weight loss of about 10 pounds over the last two months. Denies fever or chills. HEENT: Denies headaches, vision changes, or hearing problems. Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain, palpitations, or edema. Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath or cough. Gastrointestinal: Reports mild abdominal discomfort, primarily in the right upper quadrant. Mild nausea, but no vomiting. Reports decreased appetite. Denies changes in bowel habits or blood in stool. Genitourinary: Denies dysuria, frequency, or urgency. No hematuria. Musculoskeletal: Reports general muscle weakness but denies joint pain or swelling. Skin: Notes mild yellowing of skin and eyes over the past week. Denies rashes or itching. Neurological: Denies headaches, dizziness, or changes in memory. Psychiatric: Mood stable on current medication. Denies suicidal ideation. Endocrine: Denies excessive thirst or frequent urination. Hematologic: Denies easy bruising or bleeding.
Practitioner_Documents.History of Present Illness: Mr. Thibodeaux is a 50-year-old African American male with a known history of chronic hepatitis C and compensated cirrhosis, presenting today for follow-up and evaluation of worsening symptoms. He reports increasing fatigue over the past 6-8 weeks, which has begun to interfere with his part-time work as a security guard. He notes mild but persistent discomfort in the right upper quadrant of his abdomen, which he describes as a dull ache. This discomfort has been present for about a month and is not associated with eating or movement. The patient has also noticed a decrease in appetite and estimates he has lost about 10 pounds over the last two months without trying. He reports mild nausea, particularly in the mornings, but denies vomiting. Over the past week, he has observed a slight yellowing of his skin and eyes. He denies fever, chills, or night sweats. He has not noticed any changes in his bowel habits and denies any blood in his stool. The patient confirms he has been adherent to his prescribed medications and has maintained sobriety from alcohol since 2018. He expresses concern about the progression of his liver disease and its impact on his ability to work and daily activities.
Practitioner_Documents.Plan of Treatment: 1. Laboratory tests: Order comprehensive metabolic panel, complete blood count, prothrombin time/INR, and alpha-fetoprotein to assess liver function and screen for hepatocellular carcinoma. 2. Imaging: Schedule an abdominal ultrasound to evaluate for signs of portal hypertension and screen for liver masses. 3. Medications: Continue current antiviral therapy for hepatitis C. Adjust dosage if necessary based on renal function. Prescribe lactulose for mild hepatic encephalopathy symptoms. 4. Lifestyle modifications: Reinforce importance of abstaining from alcohol. Recommend a low-sodium diet and provide nutritional counseling referral. 5. Vaccinations: Ensure patient is up-to-date on hepatitis A and B vaccinations. Recommend annual influenza vaccine and pneumococcal vaccine if not already received. 6. Monitoring: Schedule follow-up appointment in 4 weeks to review test results and reassess symptoms. Provide patient with symptoms to watch for that would require immediate medical attention. 7. Specialist referral: Refer to hepatology for evaluation for potential liver transplant candidacy given the progression of symptoms. 8. Support: Provide information on local support groups for patients with chronic liver disease. Offer referral to social services for assistance with work-related concerns. 9. Education: Discuss the importance of medication adherence and regular follow-ups. Provide written materials on managing cirrhosis symptoms.
Practitioner_Documents.Vaccine Credential Patient Assertion: Patient reports receiving hepatitis A and B vaccines in 2015 after initial hepatitis C diagnosis. Annual flu shots received, with the most recent in October 2023. Pneumococcal vaccine (PPSV23) received in 2020. COVID-19 primary series and one booster received, with the last dose in September 2022. Patient is unsure about tetanus status and has no record of shingles vaccination.

Case_Summary.Summary: This is a fictional representation of healthcare data intended for interoperability testing and solution development. The data are entirely fictitious and do not represent a real person or a real clinical scenario. The report details a 50-year-old African American male with chronic hepatitis C and compensated cirrhosis, diagnosed in 2015 and 2020 respectively. The patient, with a history of alcohol use disorder (in remission since 2018), presents with worsening symptoms including fatigue, abdominal discomfort, and mild jaundice. Recent lab work and imaging suggest disease progression. The patient is currently on antiviral therapy and medications for cirrhosis management. A hepatology referral is planned to evaluate liver transplant candidacy, reflecting the advancing nature of his condition.
